@OSacrumCorIesu I agree, that seems like a very important question to try and think about.

@OSacrumCorIesu Good point re LLF and consultation. I guess the challenge is when practice diverges from the canons so gradually over a long period it's hard to put a pin in it and have a proper LLF-style consultation.

@OSacrumCorIesu E.g. the canons are unambiguous about sex and marriage, but it'd be no good simply pointing to that and using it to close down LLF etc by saying anyone arguing for gay marriage is not a true Anglican. Don't we have to at least be open to reimagining Anglicanism beyond canon law?

@OSacrumCorIesu I guess we'd all love everyone else to align their theology and practice with ours, and for the canons to enforce our own position. But, to coexist I wonder if we need to have more flexibility about what it means to be Anglican when drawing our boundaries and bottom line.

@OSacrumCorIesu For example, the canons until v recently also demanded clergy robe up for every service. But on the ground, at least half of all clergy have ignored this for decades. Are they all fake Anglicans? Or has Anglicanism expanded by force of practice beyond what's in the law?

@OSacrumCorIesu Given evangelicals have been self professed Anglicans for centuries, contradicting canon law for most of that time without any serious censure, I'd suggest the meaning of Anglicanism must shift to encompass this.

@OSacrumCorIesu Legally you're of course totally correct. But do you not also think the meaning of Anglicanism must be captured not just by the canons but by practice also?
At least a third if not more of Anglicans have not seen weekly communions as core to Anglicanism for centuries now.

@tifferrobinson @mthr_jo Hmm. That may have been intent but evidence is suggesting even current Tier 3 failing to stop cases surging again, and this is long before half the country squeezes onto trains to start mixing with other households elsewhere.
@tifferrobinson @mthr_jo ...scrapped simply because we can predict it will soon be broken by millions for cultural, traditional reasons.

@tifferrobinson @mthr_jo Yes, but in the knowledge no-one will be arrested or charged for this. The fact is, today right now I am banned from socialising inside the house of my friends or family. I've not seen any argument which that good law which is protecting public health should be temporarily...

@KingCrawa @tifferrobinson Of course. By 'Christmas' in my original tweet I obviously meant it as a shorthand for the social gathering which is what the debate is about, not the broader concept/season of Christmas.
@tifferrobinson @mthr_jo Just the fact a majority break an unenforceable law is not a good reason to scrap the law. (See age of consent for sex as another example.)

@mthr_jo @tifferrobinson Great comparison. A large proportion of drivers ignore the 70 limit on motorways. Probably even a majority. But we know if we therefore scrapped the rule, there'd be even more speeding along the current law abiding minority, and thus more crashes and deaths.

@tifferrobinson @KingCrawa @adambecket I disagree. A proportion of people (I have no idea what number, but I'd guess it's at least a third) would cancel Christmas plans if it was literally illegal. People said the first lockdown's unprecedented restrictions would be met with massive noncompliance, but it wasn't.

@tifferrobinson @adambecket There's decent evidence the lockdowns are met with broad overall compliance though. And even if the 'Christmas at any cost' group was larger you would still significantly suppress the almost inevitable third wave in Jan if you could get only 30% to cancel Christmas plans.

@KingCrawa @tifferrobinson @adambecket Yes of course, but what the row is about is meeting other households indoors over several days, not immovable Christian festivals. There is no concrete reason that HAS to take place over 25th December in conjunction with the Christian festival - it's merely cultural tradition.
@tifferrobinson @adambecket I don't understand why we have decided because say 25% would break Covid rules at Christmas, we will lift the rules, ensuring the other 75% do the same?

@tifferrobinson @adambecket I find this argument unconvincing though. A proportion of people will always meet up whatever the law, but a larger number would forgo Christmas if it was banned. Ignore the ones who will always meet up and craft rules designed to suppress meetups by the larger law abiding group.
@tifferrobinson @adambecket Or simply decide Christmas can this year be postponed a few months until they have got their vaccines? Not worth the risk just for a turkey dinner and present exchange.

(This utterly radical idea brought to you by literally every other properly functioning democracy on Earth)

The House of Lords in its current format is irredeemably anti-democratic. The only fair solution is for people to enter the chamber by winning elections. Not party cronyism, not prime ministerial patronage, not inheriting a title from your dad. Elections.

Years of self-restraint by peers themselves to reduce the size of the chamber have all wiped out by Johnson's cronyism. But fundamentally, the idea the PM can add an UNLIMITED number of party cronies into the ACTUAL LEGISLATURE at will is obviously insane.

It is self-evident that the only sustainable route to reforming the Lords is to shift it to an elected chamber. PMs will always abuse their powers to appoint new members as history has shown ever since the hereditaries were mostly abolished. https://t.co/Y5GWDhzkO1

@jgctweets @HannahE27 @redjules I feel that Christians, especially clergy, should be more discerning about where they derive insight about themselves and others. Not only does it lack any scientific psychological credibility, it also grew out of a philosophical worldview directly at odds with Christian faith.

@jgctweets @HannahE27 @redjules ...the other stuff which is actually specific is entirely spurious, evidence-free mumbo jumbo about wings and lines connecting different personality types, none of which has a shred of hard fact behind it.

@jgctweets @HannahE27 @redjules Because it grew out of the New Age movement in the postwar era. My objection is that it is fairly useless as a tool for understanding personality. It's insights are mostly so obvious or vague that they could be derived from almost anywhere...

@tifferrobinson @JwhiteRev If you work best by taking short breaks off each day for an hour or two as rest, that's easy enough to implement, but if instead you want to work five full 8-hour days and then rest for two in a row, many diocese/bishops/parishes will strongly resist.

@tifferrobinson @JwhiteRev For some, I agree. But my concern is the national church expectation/culture of six days makes it very hard for those clergy who believe (for good reason IMO) five days is their line to make that a boundary.

@tifferrobinson @WalkerMarcus But two days off in a row once a month is pretty thin gruel Tiffer! Nobody else in any other vocation or profession would see that as a perk, but instead falling well short of a normal healthy pattern of work.

@NivLobo @jonnyguyism @UCCF Very interesting point. It is helpful to see 'full-time working Christians' who aren't clergy model this restraint and discipline on hours well, as many vicars from all tribes refuse to draw lesson from other workers or professionals in 'secular' industries.

@tifferrobinson @JwhiteRev But that is precisely the issue, no? Given the work will always exceed the hours God has sent, we have to choose not to let the volume of work determine working patterns in the first place. Decide where to draw boundaries based on what is healthy and wise, not most productive.

@JwhiteRev @tifferrobinson My question is, if we are OK with drawing a line and saying six days is enough, why not align with what everyone has already concluded and stop at five days, giving yourself a more reasonable rest of two days a week.

@JwhiteRev @tifferrobinson Absolutely agree. There is always more work to be done but wise clergy will set boundaries and say 'Enough!'. This already happens with the well-established one day off a week, it's not that parochial work is always finished in six days, but vicars choose to stop anyway.

@NivLobo @jonnyguyism @UCCF Exactly. For instance, why shouldn't a vicar take some TOIL if they have to chair a 3-hour PCC meeting in the evening? Or if they have to do a wedding on a Saturday which would otherwise be their day off? Why is that seen as a radical or daring suggestion?
@NivLobo @jonnyguyism Absolutely!
@tifferrobinson Clearly there is a huge range of experiences of the clergy, but the majority of clergy I speak with have more 'church' work than they can actually fit into six working days.
@Mr_Sam_Brown Enjoy your time off Sam!
@NivLobo @jonnyguyism This is a very important lesson we all, but especially clergy, need to learn.

@tifferrobinson Even if this true (which for me it normally isn't to be honest), a ton of clergy absolutely do not have the time to do stuff like car maintenance or personal admin during their working hours.

@jonnyguyism 100% agree. It also points to huge problem of clericalism among the laity of the church - unable/unwilling to do anything unless the vicar is leading, which creates this impossible volume of work.

@jonnyguyism Unfortunately, I think the culture won't change until a new generation of vicars take the difficult step of refusing to work the sixth day, resisting the enormous pressure from congregation, peers and diocese. So I fear it's on your shoulders - which isn't fair at all.

@chingford_lad I know some teachers who do work very long hours, but none who think this is a good thing. Most see overworked teachers as a symptom of our failure to properly fund and organise our school system.

And yet simultaneously, the church has got to a place where we expect clergy to work six days a week plus tons of evening events. And in some quarters even the solitary day off is viewed with suspicion.

If there was a parishioner who was working 6 days a week plus a heap of evening meetings, even in the most important job in the world, most vicars would gently try to pastor them about overwork, stress, career idolatry, impact on family life...
No cleric would tell a doctor in their church who felt a strong God-given vocation to healthcare that this meant they should work six days a week, because 'it's not a job, it's a vocation'.

And simply replying 'It's a vocation not a job' is not an argument - are the nurses, scientists, firefighters etc in your congregation (dare I even add, journalists) also not pursuing their vocation? Yet they all strive not to overwork and take two days off a week (or equivalent)
Hard to see the Church properly tackling burnout and clergy wellbeing until it takes this excellent question more seriously. https://t.co/Gy5Lmg1ng4

Coming up soon we will have episodes about some of the ethical dilemmas people face during pandemics, including how to triage patients when you don't have enough ventilators or beds for everyone.

The most recent episode zooms in some theological questions the pandemic has thrown up. We chatted about the sovereignty of God, preparing for death, redemption in suffering, faith growing through times of testing and stuff like that. https://t.co/VGsjmxfIzE

@MadsDavies This is true. But quite troubling if the mission which inspires journalists to do their jobs is one the public actively does not want them to achieve. Not sure what we do about that.

@MadsDavies Mmm very perceptive. Hadn't thought about that. Journalists become an irritant because they point out the holes in the semi-mythical comfort blanket we have created of the government knowing what it's doing.

@drgavinm That's a really interesting idea. I think you're probably right politicians must take a share of the blame for the Punch and Judy game press conferences have become and which turns off so many people.

@jonnyguyism Yeah I hear that and kind of agree myself. Perhaps some political journalists haven't quite realised this is a public health story not a Westminster bubble story and need to adjust their tone/style a bit.
@jonnyguyism And almost regardless of where you fall on that debate, it's probably not healthy for the media to believe one thing about how it does its job, and for the public to strongly disagree.

@jonnyguyism This is the fascinating thing. Almost all journalists I know/follow, from any outlet or any political leaning, think the adversarial questions are totally proper. While large swathes of the public think they're wrong.
How have the media fallen so low in the public's trust that we're despised by the nation even as we try to uncover malfeasance by those in high office *on the public's behalf*?

What does it mean for a democracy when a significant portion of its citizens think its journalists are doing something wrong by trying to hold the government to account? Should/could the media try to persuade the public they're wrong on this?

Obviously this is silliness, but journalists like me who are rolling their eyes or dunking on it should perhaps reflect on how widespread this sentiment is. I've certainly heard it often. https://t.co/QaqvaGo0jb

@RevDavidMilford But then there is a whole raft of middling size places which could conceivably be either, and although they do have a formal legal designation as city or not city, in everyday language native speakers switch between the two quite naturally.

@RevDavidMilford I sympathise - it's more of a gut sense about the place (i.e., no-one would think to call London a town or St Ives a city) rather than any formal dictionary definition you can fall back on.
Perhaps this might say something about whether the designation of town or city is helpful to public discourse?
St Asaph, population 3,355 and an economically irrelevant North Welsh village, is a city but Milton Keynes - population 230,000 and a significant and growing business location - is a town.

Perhaps, and this is just thinking out loud, our regional investment and development policy shouldn't be based on a nebulous and ultimately impossible to prove definition of what is a town and what is a city?

It's almost like, and bear with me here, the distinction between 'towns' and 'cities' is almost entirely semantic and subjective, and native English speakers switch between the two as de facto synonyms for lots of middling size places. https://t.co/uvPn9bxOeV

@BishopBangor @MirandaTHolmes No problem at all with the spirituality and traditions of advent being used in the build up to Christmas, there's lots of great stuff in there. The problem is when clergy try to stifle non churchy people's efforts to celebrate Christmas because it's technically the wrong season.
And this doesn't remotely mean abandoning all the great stuff about Advent, the significance of waiting and hope. You can easily fold that into your celebrating with a bit of imagination.

If you want to do your own personal traditonal festivities running from the 24th into January, knock yourself out. But it's a gross failure of mission and imagination to not join in with those outside the church for whom Christmas season starts in mid Nov.

The one time of year non-Christians actually want to celebrate Jesus with you, and we're trying to pompously tell them off because Christmas season doesn't technically begin until 24 Dec? Do me a favour.

@IfADoubleDecker They were genuinely and inexplicably very popular among my friends in London. People who until about 2015 would have never considered getting an equally cheap minicab around, were all of a sudden fairly regularly getting Ubers for short everyday trips.
The surprise is it has taken this long for investors and the markets to wake up to the fact Uber and WeWork and everyone else have no pathway to actually make a profit.

So not only have these companies never made a profit by squeezing their prices too low, even then they never had a mass market product. Getting meal kits sent to your door was always going to be a niche thing for the rich.

Same with meal kits. The firms may have subsidised the costs to build market share, but even then it has always been two, three or four times cheaper to go out and buy the ingredients yourself at a supermarket.
Even though Uber lost money on every single ride by setting their prices artificially low, it's still way more pricey to get an Uber around the city than just take public transport or cycle.
The crazy thing is even though these millennial lifestyle companies sell their stuff at a loss, it was still crazy expensive.  https://t.co/QkqXdmmEBG

And while it is complex, I do feel that there is value in the aspiration of journalists presenting the news to us without us having any idea what they feel about the news.
Whether that is a good rule or not is another debate, but I do feel many of those livid at the BBC haven't seen/heard what the complaints unit actually objected to.

i.e. fine to call obviously racist comments by Trump racist, and also fine to share your own experience of also experiencing horrible racism. Not fine to then say you are 'furious' at Trump's racist comments.

His objection was to what she said next, when Dan asks how it makes her feel, and she says 'Absolutely furious'. Jordan argues this breaches impartiality requirements, as viewers shouldn't be able to tell presenter's personal views on matters of public controversy.

I really think a major part of the furore around @BBCNaga is that the clip everyone sees on Twitter cuts off before the end of her discussion with @mrdanwalker. Everything she says in this shorter clip is absolutely fine BBC editorial boss David Jordan said this morning.

She really is just not very good at politics. Every single time she cannot resist some more pointless can-kicking which will only cause more problems down the line. No foresight, no courage, no strength of character. Not even basic political guile and strategy. Hopeless.

Instead, she stubbornly, against all the evidence and obvious knowledge of her audience, insists her original line/plan will still happen, until suddenly it is not happening. It was the same with the early general election too.

She is too weak and short-sighted to make what is a short-term politically painful admission ('Brexit may have to be delayed', 'the extension is likely to be longer than I want' or 'immigration is difficult to lower') but in long-term would help her out when reality crashes in.

She does this ALL the time. Continues insisting something she knows cannot happen just to keep the line until she has to do an embarrassing reverse ferret. 'We are still leaving on 29 March' or 'We will not do Euro elections' or 'Immigration will come down below 100k'.

In literally a few hours' time the EU will offer her a longer extension which she will be forced to accept. And then this June deadline insistence will be held over her head yet again as more evidence of her failure.

This is classic May. She knows, as all in Westminster do, the EU Council are never going to give her an extension only to June. It will either be 9-12 months or no extension. But it's politically painful to admit that today, so she still insists it will only be June. https://t.co/WQ7Ts52sUB
